Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> Exactly, which is exactly why you should be humble when you ship your code
> and open it up. 

No, exactly the opposite. Until you know what you need to open and why 
you need to open it, keep it closed. That is humility. Do not assume you 
can guess what will and will not be useful without foreknowledge of how 
the library will be used.

> Assume that people will use it in ways you didn't think of,
> and make it possible for them to do so in ways that you control (always an
> interesting exercise, by the way, it forces you to think out of the box and
> to break your habits).
> 
> Michael showed a pretty compelling case where the vendor forgot to make
> their methods virtual, and I've seen this mistake and more general ones so
> many times in dozens of API's and libraries I wish people locked down their
> code a lot less.

You seem to be assuming that a library is a fixed piece of code that can 
never change. That isn't the case. When a new need arises, new features 
can be added to the library to support it. However, some changes are 
easier than others. I don't know C++ well enough to know if it's easy or 
hard to change a function from non-virtual to virtual. However the 
equivalent in Java (final to non-final) is straightforward. The reverse 
operation is not. Be very cautious before committing to an irreversible 
operation.

Closed doors can be opened, but open doors cannot be closed. If you 
later discover that you didn't design the API quite right, take the 
right arguments, set the proper preconditions, or generally do the right 
thing, it's really hard to fix it. Too much code already depends on the 
old, buggy, poorly designed behavior.

Because I am humble and know that I do not know how people will use my 
code, I restrict myself to what I do know. I limit myself to the 
simplest thing that could possibly work until it's obvious that my 
solution no longer can work, and a more complex solution is necessary.
